5/5

Our constitutional system suffers when it looks like the Justices of the Supreme Court—the very people we entrust to maintain the rule of law—think that they, themselves, are above the law.

4/

Recent events—whether it be the unprecedented leak of a draft opinion, speeches given at closed-door events with parties to ongoing cases in front of the Court, or public appearances with political figures—all call out for scrutiny under a defined code of ethics.

3/

People are justifiably shocked when they learn that not only is there no code of conduct for the Supreme Court, but that the justices have steadfastly opposed the creation of one. 

2/

We expect the justices of our nation’s highest court to hold themselves to the highest standards of ethical conduct, but, in fact, their conduct too often falls below the standards that most other government officials are required to follow.

To women and LGBTQ folks across this country: know that I’m mad as hell and fighting with everything I have to stand up to this draconian, extremist attack on your rights.
The freedom of millions of Americans is at risk. We must use EVERY tool we have to protect reproductive freedom, including abolishing the filibuster to pass this legislation.

I ran and won against one of the last anti-abortion and anti-LBGTQ+ Democrats in Congress. And it is exactly why I’m not going to let a group of unelected old white men tell me or my daughter what we can or cannot do with our own bodies or with the people we love.

I am terrified that not just Roe, but other crucial rights now appear to be up for debate.
 
As the mother of a transgender woman, I am deeply worried that her rights will be struck down next. This decision is dangerous for marginalized communities across the country.

I know first-hand that the freedom to decide when and under what circumstances to raise a family is crucial to gender equality and the principle that government can and should not interfere with personal medical decisions.

I’m grateful for the decision I made more than 30 years ago. I’m even more grateful to have had the freedom to make that decision.
 
I had a life ahead of me that would eventually put me in a place where I would one day be ready to start a family.

When I found out I was pregnant, I was only 19 years old and barely halfway through college. There was no way I could afford to have a baby.
 
A few days after my positive pregnancy test, I visited a local reproductive care clinic to have an abortion.

I never intended to share the story of my abortion publicly.
 
But with the Supreme Court set to upend a half-century guaranteed right to an abortion in the United States, I felt it was necessary. https://twitter.com/cnnopinion/status/1524530864943767552 QT @CNNOpinion Abortion "can restore hope and a sense of possibility to women who find themselves in the position of needing one," writes @RepMarieNewman.
